reviewText: Demonic Toys starts out fast and fun, and for a while I felt like I was watching a lost entry in the Child's Play series. However, about midway through the movie lost me with some dumb satanic stuff that just changed the tone of the film.Demonic Toys is entertaining enough for fans of killer doll movies, but it's not as good as any of the Chucky movies. Even Child's Play 3 is slightly more enjoyable than this. Rated R for graphic violence, some nudity, and lots of swearing.
summary: These Toys Make The Perfect Christmas Gift!

reviewText: Great Full Moon movie, definitely up there in the top 5. This transfer is really nice except for an occasional warping issue that happens semi frequently throughout the film. The original negatives were probably not stored in the best conditions, which may be cause of the warping, or it may be the company that did the transfer, but it doesn't ruin the overall high quality bluray standards being brought to this title for the first time. The Dollman bluray also has the same issue, but is also the best transfer to date. It's like seeing the films for the first time, but something tells me Charles Band is paying the absolute minimum to get the job done.
summary: Bluray Transfer warping problems may or may not be damage to original print

Then she and the bad guy end up in a Toy Factory where things are most definitely NOT cute and cuddly. My favourite toy is "Baby Oops A Daisy" who informs the Security guard that she can walk and talk and then she shoots him!!!Put your brain into nuetral gear and sit back and enjoy this movie!!!

reviewText: They're cute and cuddly by day, lethal demons by night. Ruthless killing machines come alive for just one purpose...death. And for five adults trapped in an abandoned warehouse, every child's worst nightmare has become a deadly reality...While on a stakeout, Judith Gray (Tracy Scoggins), a beautiful, tough cop, is trapped inside a warehouse full of toys. But these are no ordinary playthings--they have been awakened to murderous life by a strange child of darkness, "The Kid" (Daniel Cerny). Each toy feeds on blood: Jack-in-the-Box heads straight for the throat; Teddy Bear is not afraid to show its claws; and Baby Doll is truly to die for. Now it's up to Gray and a passing delivery boy, Mark Wayne (Bentley Mitchum), to stop the deadly, DEMONIC TOYS!
summary: They Want To Play With You...!!!!!!!!

reviewText: Full Moon Picture's Demonic Dolls may put some people off by its plot description or the company's reputation with the Puppetmaster series, and admittedly I passed it by the first few times myself before giving it a chance, but I was glad when I did because it managed to be an entertaining, nasty little surprise.Police officer Judith Gray (Tracy Scoggins) has great news to share with her live-in boyfriend. They're going to have a baby. All right, in ideal circumstances a surprise like this isn't always the best of news but through the turn of events of the night we don't see the couple go through the normal parental joys or woes concerning pregnancy. She probably should have broken the news at a better time (they were waiting in a car getting ready for a bust for crying out loud), but I won't spend any more time in this review expressing my opinion on her timing.Long story short, the undercover drug deal goes bad, and Judith ends up with both prisoners outside of an abandoned toy warehouse. One man is shot and wounded while one is retained by the cop and is dragged around in handcuffs inside the building. Also inside is a laid-back obese security guard reading dirty magazines and making fast-food orders on the company phone. Mark, the take-out guy, arrives and stops in to chitchat with the guard while getting paid. Suddenly disaster unwinds and the crew gets barred in with...du-du-dum!...DEMONIC TOYS!Apparently there is a demonic spirit that has been resting for ages and now animates the toys to life, just waiting for his chance to make it out into the world. The way he's planning to do that will remain a secret forr if you ever get the chance to watch this yourself.One toy is a baby doll that would put a truck driver to shame with its mouth. This thing swears every twist and turn of the way and turns out to be the main toy shown. Its sidekick is a jack-in-the-box (yes they have something for people with the classic clown phobias too) with an eerie painted on grin and razor-sharp teeth accompanied by a piercing, maniacal giggle. We also get soldiers with firing guns and an interesting array of other toys armed with deadly weaponry.As a few die another character shows up. Her name is Anne, a runaway girl who had it rough -- or thought she did before started living in the warehouse of THIS movie. More on the others - Mark, the delivery guy, is cute as a button and I really dug his personality. Judith is tough, pretty, and a competent actress. She's not over-tough either, but realistic. The other people are just there for cool deaths, the above mentioned were my favorites.Some of the death scenes are  really painful to behold -- especially the guards! Some decent blood and slosh action. The toys are freaky enough (demonic toys always are), there's some cheesiness (of course), and some morbid demented humor -- especially from the garbage mouthed baby.The demon mainly takes form as a little boy. When he speaks its through a deep voice that's achieved through voice amplifiers. Ultra cool. Judith experiences weird visions and flashbacks about the boy, and there's a bunch of other little goodies thrown in this movie too.The movie starts out with character interaction and a fast pace and keeps it up all the way through. Whether one likes this movie or not I doubt it would ever be called boring. The acting is competent, the script is unique (if you ignore that killer toys has been done hundreds of times before), and effects aren't the best but they're fun.The ending is a small let-down as it was a bit too silly, even for this film, but it worked and I was left knowing all was resolved. I haven't seen Demonic Toys Vs. Dolls yet and can't imagine how that would work but admit I'm curious.So what if the plot is predictable? With a title like DEMONIC TOYS we're not going in for a blockbuster, we're going into see some bodies strung up and slashed open by evil possessed creatures. Full Moon put all their go into this one and it shows.

reviewText: Don't get me wrong; the first half drags as we watch a bad version of Flashpoint playing out.  (Officer down, and she doesn't use her radio/walkie talkie/communications device/radio in the car to call for backup?)  After an agonizingly slow beginning, though, things begin to look up. It's refreshing to watch this woman actually try to use the telephone she is standing right next to.  Also, the protagonists do bother to take some extra ammo and reload their guns from time to time (although in a key scene you would think a double barreled shotgun had six or eight shots instead of two.) The second half is much more interesting, although my mind boggles at what they missed.  How about stuffed bunnies that fly at you, wrap around your face, and suffocate you? The ending was quite intriguing, so I can't really write this one off altogether.
Title: N/A

reviewText: From David Goyer, the writer of such contemporary science-fiction hits as Blade, Dark City, Batman Begins and The Dark Knight, comes the cheesy cult film Demonic Toys. Not to be forgotten amongst his successes (although keep in mind he also wrote Jumper), Demonic Toys is a hilarious little schlock film that reminds us how much fun possessed toys can be when they murder, torture and sexually assault unsuspecting victims.Judith Gray (Tracy Scoggins) has been having particularly strange nightmares, but shrugs them off when on the battlefield of city streets, cleaning up crime as an undercover cop. During a routine drug bust, psychotic gun dealers Hesse and Lincoln kill Judith's partner, and escape to a rundown toy warehouse. Hesse dies from a bullet wound, but not before bleeding all over a demonic section of the facility, awakening an evil spirit. The demon has been attempting to secure a female human body to be reborn in, and Judith happens to be an ideal candidate. It gains control of several of the toys in the building and proceeds to terrorize the unsuspecting dupes caught in the wrong place at the wrong time.A slathering of side characters emerge, mainly for newly possessed knickknacks to wreak havoc upon. Controlled by the demon, a mutant jack-in-the-box, a knife-wielding, vulgarity-spewing baby doll (named Oopsy Daisy), a fanged teddy bear, and an electronic laser-armed robot hunt for our cliché heroes. Aside from Judith, who alternates keeping her cool and screaming wildly, there's Anne, who wanders the warehouse through air vents (much like Newt in Aliens) Mark, a chicken delivery guy with an overabundance of `tude (much like Hudson in Aliens), and Charnetski, the typical overweight security guard who supplies the much-needed shotgun (there's really no one like this in Aliens).Mark runs his mouth (Chunky Chicken Christ!) with laughably bad dialogue (or appropriately B-movie verbiage) and desperately needs a slap in the face (but wait - he get's one!). At one point he even looks at his watch, shortly after being knocked out by a hulking giant teddy bear monster, not to check the time but to ponder how long this movie drags on. Little girls on tricycles with gasmasks fill in the spots that are missing absurd hallucinations, along with a very naked Miss July, a junior demon with a hard-on, and hilarious moments of dispatching toys with incredibly destructive firepower.The foul-mouthed Baby Oopsy Daisy evokes constant laughs, as does the nonsensical conversations and pointless characters. Full Moon Studios, who brought us tons of other evil toy movies (see Puppet Master and Blood Dolls) doesn't have any qualms with redundancy. But for all of the poor effects and pitiful plot points that spring from Demonic Toys, the utter cheesiness of the film is devilishly entertaining.- Mike Massie
summary: Demonic Toys Movie Review from The Massie Twins

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: After an arms deal gone bad, a policeman is shot and the arms traffickers head into a toy warehouse followed by policewoman Tracy Scoggins. The toys in this warehouse suddenly become alive due to demonic possession that is explained by the demon himself. Of course only the toys that have long razor sharp teeth and can be made to look like they are attacking people as an evil hand puppet, come to life. There is a fairly good cast of characters. Special effects are not that great, but we've seen worse. The toys have some great lines and it comical watching humans struggle against the attack of a small toy. The demonic thing with kids was a bit hokey and didn't work that well, but we watch it for Baby Oopsy-Daisy.Tracy Scoggins dropping the F-bomb, nudity (Playboy's Kristine Rose), Tracy tied down spread eagle.
summary: I'm Baby Oopsy-Daisy, will you be my special friend?

reviewText: The title alone should suggest it. Demonic Toys. Taking place in a toy factory late at night and featuring such colorful villains as Baby Oopsy Daisy and Jack Attack, this movie delivers the goods. There are some great gore scenes throughout the movie which always adds points in horror films. The setting adds a classic spooky touch that adds to the effect of the movie (after all, setting is big in horror). We have comical characters that get developed throughout the movie. The really interesting thing is how there are several mini-plots that get kicked off at the beginning of the movie, and they all come together as the movie progresses. In a way, it's almost like the Seinfeld of horror movies in terms of the story-writing. There are a few jokes that bomb here and there, but overall this movie does an excellent job at combining humor with slapstick gore and fantasy terror. Oh, and who wouldn't want to see a horror film with imaginary girls in hazmat masks riding around on tricycles? Highly recommended! Thanks for the time and peace.
summary: Everything glorious about the B-movie rolled into one!
Title: N/A
